canonical_explanation.text:
Breathing (ventilation) is the mechanical process of moving air in and out of the lungs, while respiration encompasses the entire process of gas exchange and cellular utilisation of oxygen. The human respiratory system consists of the external nostrils, nasal cavities, pharynx, larynx, trachea, bronchi, bronchioles and alveoli. The lungs are situated in the thoracic cavity and are enclosed by a double-layered pleural membrane. Each lung contains approximately 300 million alveoli, providing a large surface area (~100 m2) for gas exchange.

Breathing involves two phases: inspiration (inhalation) and expiration (exhalation), regulated by the contraction and relaxation of the diaphragm and external/internal intercostal muscles. Pulmonary volumes include tidal volume (TV, ~500 mL), inspiratory reserve volume (IRV, ~2500-3000 mL), expiratory reserve volume (ERV, ~1000-1100 mL) and residual volume (RV, ~1100-1200 mL). Vital capacity = TV + IRV + ERV (~3400-4800 mL). Gas exchange at the alveolar surface occurs by simple diffusion, driven by partial pressure differences. Oxygen is transported in blood as oxyhaemoglobin (~97%) and dissolved in plasma (~3%). The oxygen-haemoglobin dissociation curve is sigmoid-shaped, and factors like high pCO2, low pH, high temperature and high 2,3-DPG shift the curve to the right (Bohr effect), facilitating O2 release in tissues. CO2 is transported as dissolved CO2 (~7%), as bicarbonate ions (~70%, via chloride shift) and as carbaminohaemoglobin (~23%). Respiration is regulated by the respiratory centre in the medulla oblongata, with input from chemoreceptors sensitive to CO2 and H+ ion concentrations. Common respiratory disorders include asthma, emphysema, occupational lung diseases and lung cancer.
rules: Inspiration is an active process involving contraction of the diaphragm (flattens) and external intercostal muscles (lift the ribs), increasing thoracic volume and decreasing intrapulmonary pressure.
Expiration is normally a passive process involving relaxation of the diaphragm and external intercostal muscles, decreasing thoracic volume and increasing intrapulmonary pressure.
Tidal volume (TV) is ~500 mL; inspiratory reserve volume (IRV) is ~2500-3000 mL; expiratory reserve volume (ERV) is ~1000-1100 mL; residual volume (RV) is ~1100-1200 mL.
Vital capacity (VC) = TV + IRV + ERV; total lung capacity (TLC) = VC + RV.
Gas exchange at the alveolar surface occurs by simple diffusion along partial pressure gradients: O2 moves from alveoli (pO2 ~104 mmHg) to blood, and CO2 moves from blood (pCO2 ~45 mmHg) to alveoli.
Each haemoglobin molecule can bind four O2 molecules; the O2-Hb dissociation curve is sigmoid (S-shaped).
The Bohr effect: high pCO2, low pH and high temperature shift the O2-Hb dissociation curve to the right, promoting O2 release in active tissues.
CO2 is transported as: dissolved in plasma (~7%), bicarbonate ions in plasma (~70%, formed by carbonic anhydrase in RBCs), and carbaminohaemoglobin (~23%).
The chloride shift (Hamburger's phenomenon) maintains electrical neutrality when HCO3- ions move out of RBCs into plasma and Cl- ions move in.
The respiratory centre in the medulla oblongata controls the rate and depth of breathing; pneumotaxic centre in the pons moderates the respiratory centre.
Chemoreceptors in the aortic arch and carotid body detect changes in CO2, O2 and H+ levels in blood and signal the respiratory centre.
Asthma involves bronchospasm and difficulty in breathing; emphysema involves alveolar wall damage and reduced gas exchange surface area.

questions.question_text: The structural and functional unit of gas exchange in the lungs is the:
questions.explanation_correct: The alveolus (plural: alveoli) is the structural and functional unit of gas exchange in the lungs. Each alveolus is a thin-walled, balloon-like structure surrounded by a dense network of blood capillaries, where exchange of O2 and CO2 occurs by diffusion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bronchi and bronchioles are conducting airways that transport air to the alveoli but are not the sites of gas exchange. The trachea (windpipe) is the main airway connecting the larynx to the bronchi.

questions.question_text: During inspiration, the diaphragm:

options.text: contracts and flattens, increasing thoracic volume.

questions.explanation_correct: During inspiration, the diaphragm contracts and flattens (moves downward), which increases the volume of the thoracic cavity. This decreases the intrapulmonary pressure below atmospheric pressure, causing air to rush into the lungs.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Relaxation and dome-shaping of the diaphragm occurs during expiration, not inspiration. The diaphragm moves downward during inspiration, not upward.

questions.question_text: Which muscles are involved in normal quiet inspiration?

options.text: Internal intercostal muscles and abdominal muscles
Internal and external intercostal muscles together

questions.explanation_correct: During normal quiet inspiration, the diaphragm contracts and flattens, and the external intercostal muscles contract to lift the ribs upward and outward. Both actions increase the thoracic volume and decrease intrapulmonary pressure, drawing air into the lungs.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Internal intercostal muscles are involved in forced expiration, not inspiration. Abdominal muscles assist in forced expiration. During quiet inspiration, only the diaphragm and external intercostals are active.

questions.question_text: Normal quiet expiration is primarily a:

options.text: active process involving contraction of external intercostal muscles.
passive process involving relaxation of the diaphragm and external intercostal muscles.
active process involving contraction of abdominal muscles.
process that requires ATP for muscle contraction.

questions.explanation_correct: Normal quiet expiration is primarily a passive process. When the diaphragm and external intercostal muscles relax, the thoracic cavity returns to its original smaller volume due to elastic recoil of the lungs and thoracic wall. This increases intrapulmonary pressure and pushes air out.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Active contraction of muscles is not needed during quiet expiration. Abdominal muscles and internal intercostals are recruited only during forced expiration.

questions.question_text: The tidal volume (TV) in a healthy adult is approximately:
questions.explanation_correct: Tidal volume (TV) is the volume of air inspired or expired during a normal breath. In a healthy adult, it is approximately 500 mL. This is the baseline volume exchanged during quiet, relaxed breathing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 150 mL is approximately the dead space volume. 2500-3000 mL is the inspiratory reserve volume. 4800 mL is approximately the vital capacity.

questions.question_text: Vital capacity (VC) is defined as:
questions.explanation_correct: Vital capacity (VC) = Tidal Volume (TV) + Inspiratory Reserve Volume (IRV) + Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV). It represents the maximum volume of air that can be breathed out after a maximum inspiration. In a healthy adult, it is approximately 3400-4800 mL.
questions.explanation_incorrect: TV + IRV is the inspiratory capacity, not vital capacity. TV + IRV + ERV + RV is the total lung capacity (TLC). IRV + ERV does not include tidal volume.

questions.question_text: The residual volume (RV) is the volume of air that:

options.text: remains in the lungs after a maximum forceful expiration.
can be additionally inspired after a normal inspiration.
is exchanged during one minute of breathing.

questions.explanation_correct: Residual volume (RV) is the volume of air that remains in the lungs even after a maximum forceful expiration. It is approximately 1100-1200 mL. This air cannot be expelled voluntarily and prevents the lungs from collapsing completely.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The volume inspired during normal breathing is tidal volume. The additional volume that can be inspired is IRV. The volume exchanged per minute is minute ventilation.

questions.question_text: A person has a tidal volume of 500 mL and breathes 15 times per minute. The pulmonary ventilation (minute ventilation) is:
questions.explanation_correct: Pulmonary ventilation (minute ventilation) = Tidal Volume x Respiratory rate = 500 mL x 15 breaths/min = 7500 mL/min. This represents the total volume of air moved in and out of the lungs per minute.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct calculation is 500 x 15 = 7500 mL/min. Other options result from incorrect multiplication or using wrong values.

questions.question_text:
Consider the following statements about lung volumes and capacities:
(i) Inspiratory capacity = TV + IRV
(ii) Functional residual capacity = ERV + RV
(iii) Total lung capacity = Vital capacity + Residual volume
(iv) Vital capacity = Total lung capacity - IRV
Which of the above are correct?
questions.explanation_correct: Statements (i), (ii) and (iii) are correct. IC = TV + IRV, FRC = ERV + RV, and TLC = VC + RV. Statement (iv) is incorrect — Vital capacity = TLC - RV (not TLC - IRV).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Vital capacity = TLC - RV. Subtracting IRV from TLC would give ERV + RV + TV - IRV, which is not equal to vital capacity.

questions.question_text:
Assertion (A): Air enters the lungs during inspiration because intrapulmonary pressure becomes lower than atmospheric pressure.
Reason (R): Contraction of the diaphragm and external intercostal muscles increases the volume of the thoracic cavity.
Select the correct option:

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true but R is false.
A is false but R is true.

questions.explanation_correct: Both are true and the reason correctly explains the assertion. When the diaphragm contracts (flattens) and external intercostal muscles contract (lift ribs), thoracic volume increases. According to Boyle's law, this increase in volume decreases the intrapulmonary pressure below atmospheric pressure, and air flows into the lungs.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The reason is the correct mechanistic explanation for why intrapulmonary pressure decreases during inspiration.

questions.question_text: The correct pathway of air from the external nostrils to the alveoli is:

options.text: External nostrils → Nasal cavity → Larynx → Pharynx → Trachea → Bronchi → Bronchioles → Alveoli
External nostrils → Nasal cavity → Pharynx → Larynx → Trachea → Bronchi → Bronchioles → Alveoli
External nostrils → Pharynx → Nasal cavity → Trachea → Larynx → Bronchi → Alveoli
External nostrils → Nasal cavity → Trachea → Pharynx → Larynx → Bronchi → Bronchioles → Alveoli

questions.explanation_correct: The correct pathway is: External nostrils → Nasal cavity → Pharynx → Larynx → Trachea → Primary bronchi → Secondary bronchi → Bronchioles → Terminal bronchioles → Alveolar ducts → Alveoli. The pharynx comes before the larynx.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The pharynx (common passage for food and air) must come before the larynx (voice box). The trachea connects the larynx to the bronchi. Any other arrangement is anatomically incorrect.

questions.question_text: The pleural membranes enclose a fluid-filled space called the pleural cavity. The pleural fluid:

options.text: reduces friction during breathing movements and maintains surface tension.
produces mucus to trap dust particles.

questions.explanation_correct: The pleural fluid present between the visceral and parietal pleural membranes reduces friction between the lungs and the thoracic wall during breathing movements. It also helps maintain the lungs in an expanded state through surface tension.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gas exchange occurs at the alveolar surface. Surfactant is secreted by type II alveolar cells. Mucus for trapping particles is produced by goblet cells in the respiratory tract.

questions.question_text:
Match the following respiratory volumes with their approximate values:
(a) Tidal Volume - (i) ~2500-3000 mL
(b) IRV - (ii) ~1100-1200 mL
(c) ERV - (iii) ~500 mL
(d) RV - (iv) ~1000-1100 mL
Select the correct option:
questions.explanation_correct: Tidal Volume (TV) = ~500 mL, Inspiratory Reserve Volume (IRV) = ~2500-3000 mL, Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV) = ~1000-1100 mL, Residual Volume (RV) = ~1100-1200 mL. These are standard values for a healthy adult.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct matching follows NCERT standard values for respiratory volumes in a healthy adult.

questions.question_text: Each human lung contains approximately how many alveoli?
questions.explanation_correct: Each human lung contains approximately 300 million alveoli, providing a total surface area of about 100 square metres for gas exchange. This enormous surface area is essential for efficient exchange of respiratory gases.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The number is approximately 300 million per lung (or about 600 million total in both lungs), not 3 million, 30 million or 3 billion.

questions.question_text: The inspiratory reserve volume (IRV) is the:

options.text: volume of air remaining in the lungs after normal expiration.
additional volume of air that can be inspired forcefully after a normal inspiration.
additional volume of air that can be expired forcefully after a normal expiration.
volume of air that cannot be expelled even after forceful expiration.

questions.explanation_correct: Inspiratory reserve volume (IRV) is the additional volume of air that can be inspired forcefully after a normal (tidal) inspiration. It is approximately 2500-3000 mL and represents the reserve capacity for deep breathing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Air remaining after normal expiration is functional residual capacity. Additional air that can be expired forcefully is ERV. Air that cannot be expelled is residual volume.

questions.question_text: Which of the following lung capacities CANNOT be measured using a simple spirometer?
questions.explanation_correct: Total lung capacity (TLC) = VC + RV. Since residual volume (RV) is the air that remains in the lungs even after maximum expiration and cannot be expelled, it cannot be measured directly by a simple spirometer. Therefore, TLC also cannot be determined by spirometry alone.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Vital capacity, inspiratory capacity and tidal volume can all be measured directly using a spirometer because they involve volumes of air that can be breathed in or out.

questions.question_text: Gas exchange between alveolar air and blood occurs by:

options.text: Simple diffusion along partial pressure gradients

questions.explanation_correct: Gas exchange at the alveolar surface occurs by simple diffusion along partial pressure gradients. O2 diffuses from alveoli (high pO2 ~104 mmHg) to blood capillaries (low pO2 ~40 mmHg), and CO2 diffuses from blood (high pCO2 ~45 mmHg) to alveoli (low pCO2 ~40 mmHg).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gas exchange does not require ATP (active transport), water movement (osmosis) or carrier proteins (facilitated diffusion). It is purely a physical process of diffusion.

questions.question_text: What percentage of oxygen is transported in blood as oxyhaemoglobin?
questions.explanation_correct: About 97% of oxygen is transported in blood bound to haemoglobin as oxyhaemoglobin (HbO2). Only about 3% is dissolved in plasma. Haemoglobin has a high affinity for oxygen and each molecule can carry four O2 molecules.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 3% is the dissolved form. 23% and 70% are percentages related to CO2 transport (as carbaminohaemoglobin and bicarbonate respectively), not O2 transport.

questions.question_text: Each molecule of haemoglobin can bind a maximum of:
questions.explanation_correct: Each haemoglobin molecule consists of four subunits, each containing a haem group with an iron atom. Each iron atom can bind one molecule of oxygen. Therefore, one haemoglobin molecule can carry a maximum of four O2 molecules (Hb + 4O2 → Hb4O8).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Haemoglobin has four haem groups, not one, two or six. Each haem binds one O2, so the maximum is four O2 molecules per haemoglobin.

questions.question_text: The oxygen-haemoglobin dissociation curve is:
questions.explanation_correct: The oxygen-haemoglobin dissociation curve is sigmoid (S-shaped). This shape reflects the cooperative binding of O2 to haemoglobin — the binding of O2 to one subunit increases the affinity of the remaining subunits for O2. The curve shows that at high pO2 (lungs), Hb is nearly fully saturated, and at low pO2 (tissues), O2 is readily released.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The curve is not linear (constant rate), hyperbolic (like myoglobin) or exponential. The sigmoid shape is due to cooperative binding.

questions.question_text: The Bohr effect refers to:

options.text: increased affinity of Hb for O2 at high CO2 levels.
decreased affinity of Hb for O2 at high pCO2 and low pH, shifting the dissociation curve to the right.
increased production of CO2 in the lungs.
shift of the O2-Hb dissociation curve to the left.

questions.explanation_correct: The Bohr effect describes the decreased affinity of haemoglobin for oxygen when pCO2 increases and pH decreases (conditions found in active tissues). This shifts the O2-Hb dissociation curve to the right, facilitating the release of O2 in tissues where it is most needed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Bohr effect involves decreased (not increased) O2 affinity. It occurs in tissues, not lungs. The curve shifts to the right, not left.

questions.question_text: The major form in which CO2 is transported in blood is:
questions.explanation_correct: About 70% of CO2 is transported in blood as bicarbonate ions (HCO3-). CO2 enters RBCs and is converted to carbonic acid (H2CO3) by carbonic anhydrase, which dissociates into H+ and HCO3-. The HCO3- ions are then transported to plasma.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Only about 7% of CO2 is dissolved in plasma. About 23% is transported as carbaminohaemoglobin. CO2 is not significantly bound to albumin.

questions.question_text: The chloride shift (Hamburger's phenomenon) involves:

options.text: movement of Cl- ions from plasma into RBCs as HCO3- moves out of RBCs.
movement of Na+ ions from RBCs into plasma.
movement of K+ ions out of RBCs.
movement of CO2 from RBCs to plasma.

questions.explanation_correct: The chloride shift (Hamburger's phenomenon) is the exchange of Cl- and HCO3- ions across the RBC membrane to maintain electrical neutrality. As HCO3- ions (formed from CO2) move out of RBCs into plasma, Cl- ions move from plasma into RBCs to maintain the ionic balance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The chloride shift specifically involves the exchange of Cl- and HCO3- ions, not Na+ or K+ ions. CO2 movement is a separate process.

questions.question_text:
Consider the following statements about CO2 transport:
(i) About 7% of CO2 is carried dissolved in plasma.
(ii) About 70% is transported as bicarbonate ions.
(iii) About 23% is transported as carbaminohaemoglobin.
(iv) Carbonic anhydrase is present in plasma.
Which of the above are correct?
questions.explanation_correct: Statements (i), (ii) and (iii) are correct — 7% dissolved, 70% as bicarbonate, 23% as carbaminohaemoglobin. Statement (iv) is incorrect — carbonic anhydrase is present inside RBCs, not in plasma. This is why CO2 must enter RBCs for conversion to HCO3-.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Carbonic anhydrase is found inside red blood cells, not in the plasma. The enzyme catalyses the conversion of CO2 and H2O to H2CO3 within RBCs.

questions.question_text:
Assertion (A): In active tissues, more oxygen is released from oxyhaemoglobin.
Reason (R): Active tissues produce more CO2 and H+ ions, which decrease the affinity of haemoglobin for oxygen (Bohr effect).
Select the correct option:

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true but R is false.
A is false but R is true.

questions.explanation_correct: Both are true and the reason correctly explains the assertion. Active tissues produce more CO2 and H+ (from metabolism), which lower the pH and increase pCO2. This causes the Bohr effect — a rightward shift of the O2-Hb dissociation curve, making Hb release more O2 to the tissues.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Bohr effect is precisely the mechanism by which active tissues receive more O2. The reason is the correct explanation.

questions.question_text: The partial pressure of oxygen in the alveoli is approximately:
questions.explanation_correct: The partial pressure of oxygen (pO2) in the alveoli is approximately 104 mmHg. This is lower than atmospheric pO2 (~159 mmHg) because alveolar air is mixed with CO2 and water vapour. The difference between alveolar pO2 (104 mmHg) and deoxygenated blood pO2 (40 mmHg) drives O2 diffusion into the blood.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 40 mmHg is the pO2 of deoxygenated blood. 159 mmHg is the pO2 of atmospheric air. 45 mmHg is the pCO2 of deoxygenated blood.

questions.question_text: Carbaminohaemoglobin is formed when:

options.text: CO2 binds to the iron of haemoglobin.
CO2 binds to the amino groups of the globin part of haemoglobin.
CO binds to the iron of haemoglobin.
O2 binds to the globin part of haemoglobin.

questions.explanation_correct: Carbaminohaemoglobin (HbCO2) is formed when CO2 binds to the amino groups (-NH2) of the globin (protein) part of the haemoglobin molecule. This is different from O2, which binds to the iron atom of the haem group.
questions.explanation_incorrect: CO2 binds to the globin protein, not the iron atom. Carbon monoxide (CO) binds to the iron of haem (forming carboxyhaemoglobin). O2 binds to the iron, not globin.

questions.question_text:
Match the following with the percentage of CO2 transported:
(a) Dissolved in plasma - (i) ~23%
(b) As bicarbonate ions - (ii) ~70%
(c) As carbaminohaemoglobin - (iii) ~7%
Select the correct option:
questions.explanation_correct: About 7% of CO2 is dissolved in plasma, about 70% is transported as bicarbonate ions (HCO3-), and about 23% is transported as carbaminohaemoglobin (bound to haemoglobin). These are the three modes of CO2 transport in blood.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct percentages are: dissolved (7%), bicarbonate (70%), carbaminohaemoglobin (23%). Any other combination is incorrect.

questions.question_text: Which of the following factors would shift the oxygen-haemoglobin dissociation curve to the right?

options.text: Increase in pCO2 and decrease in pH

questions.explanation_correct: An increase in pCO2 and decrease in pH (more acidic) shifts the O2-Hb dissociation curve to the right (Bohr effect). Other factors that shift the curve right include increased temperature and increased 2,3-DPG. A right shift means Hb has lower affinity for O2, favouring O2 release to tissues.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Decrease in temperature shifts the curve to the left (increased O2 affinity). Increase in pH shifts the curve to the left. Decrease in 2,3-DPG also shifts the curve to the left.

questions.question_text: The enzyme carbonic anhydrase catalyses the reaction:
questions.explanation_correct: Carbonic anhydrase, present inside RBCs, catalyses the reversible reaction: CO2 + H2O ⇌ H2CO3 (carbonic acid). The carbonic acid then dissociates into H+ and HCO3- ions. In the lungs, the reverse reaction occurs, releasing CO2 for exhalation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: CO2 binding to Hb (forming carbaminohaemoglobin) does not require carbonic anhydrase. O2 binding to Hb is also independent of this enzyme. The enzyme is inside RBCs, not in plasma.

questions.question_text: The binding of oxygen to haemoglobin is affected by all of the following EXCEPT:
questions.explanation_correct: The binding of O2 to haemoglobin is affected by pO2, pCO2, pH, temperature and 2,3-DPG concentration. Blood group (ABO system) has no effect on O2-Hb binding as it is determined by surface antigens on RBCs, not by haemoglobin properties.
questions.explanation_incorrect: pO2, pCO2 and pH all significantly affect O2-Hb binding (as shown by the O2-Hb dissociation curve and the Bohr effect).

questions.question_text: In the lungs, what conditions favour the loading of O2 onto haemoglobin?
questions.explanation_correct: In the lungs (alveoli), there is high pO2 (~104 mmHg) and low pCO2 (~40 mmHg). These conditions favour the binding (loading) of O2 to haemoglobin, forming oxyhaemoglobin. The O2-Hb dissociation curve shifts to the left under these conditions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: High pCO2 and low pO2 are conditions found in tissues (not lungs) and favour O2 unloading. Low pH and high temperature also favour O2 release, not loading.

questions.question_text: The respiratory centre that controls the rate and depth of breathing is located in the:
questions.explanation_correct: The respiratory centre is located in the medulla oblongata of the brain. It consists of the dorsal respiratory group (inspiratory centre) and ventral respiratory group (expiratory centre). It generates rhythmic breathing movements and adjusts the rate and depth of breathing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cerebrum is responsible for voluntary control of breathing. The cerebellum coordinates movement. The spinal cord transmits signals but does not generate the respiratory rhythm.

questions.question_text: The pneumotaxic centre is located in the:
questions.explanation_correct: The pneumotaxic centre is located in the pons region of the brain. It moderates the functions of the respiratory centre in the medulla by sending inhibitory signals. It can reduce the duration of inspiration, thereby affecting the respiratory rate.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The respiratory centre is in the medulla oblongata (not the pneumotaxic centre). The hypothalamus and cerebral cortex have other functions and are not the location of the pneumotaxic centre.

questions.question_text: Chemoreceptors that detect changes in CO2 and H+ concentration in the blood are located in the:
questions.explanation_correct: Chemoreceptors that detect changes in CO2, O2 and H+ ion concentrations are located in the aortic arch (aortic bodies) and carotid body (at the bifurcation of the common carotid artery). They send signals to the respiratory centre in the medulla to adjust breathing rate and depth.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Lungs, trachea, liver, kidneys, cerebellum and spinal cord do not contain the primary chemoreceptors for respiratory regulation.

questions.question_text: An increase in blood CO2 concentration leads to:

options.text: an increase in the rate and depth of breathing.

questions.explanation_correct: An increase in blood CO2 (hypercapnia) is detected by chemoreceptors in the aortic arch and carotid body. They stimulate the respiratory centre in the medulla to increase the rate and depth of breathing, thereby expelling excess CO2 and restoring normal levels.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Increased CO2 stimulates (not decreases) breathing. The body responds by hyperventilation to remove excess CO2. Breathing does not stop or remain unchanged.

questions.question_text: Asthma is characterised by:

options.text: breakdown of alveolar walls reducing surface area for gas exchange.
spasm and inflammation of bronchi and bronchioles, causing difficulty in breathing.
accumulation of fluid in the pleural cavity.
infection of the trachea by bacteria.

questions.explanation_correct: Asthma is a chronic inflammatory disorder characterised by spasm (bronchospasm) and inflammation of the bronchi and bronchioles, along with excessive mucus secretion. This narrows the airways, making breathing difficult, especially during expiration.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Breakdown of alveolar walls is emphysema. Fluid in the pleural cavity is pleural effusion. Tracheal infection is tracheitis.

questions.question_text: Emphysema is a chronic disorder in which:

options.text: bronchial tubes become narrowed due to muscle spasm.
alveolar walls are damaged, reducing the surface area for gas exchange.

questions.explanation_correct: Emphysema is a chronic obstructive lung disease in which the alveolar walls are progressively damaged and destroyed, leading to large irregular spaces and a significant reduction in the surface area available for gas exchange. It is commonly caused by cigarette smoking.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bronchial narrowing due to spasm is asthma. Diaphragm paralysis is a neuromuscular condition. Inflammation of pleural membranes is pleurisy.

questions.question_text:
Consider the following statements about regulation of respiration:
(i) The primary stimulus for the regulation of breathing is the concentration of CO2 in the blood.
(ii) The pneumotaxic centre can increase the duration of inspiration.
(iii) Chemoreceptors in the carotid body are sensitive to CO2 and H+ ion levels.
(iv) The respiratory centre is located in the cerebral cortex.
Which of the above are correct?
questions.explanation_correct: Statements (i) and (iii) are correct. CO2 concentration is the primary chemical stimulus for breathing regulation. Chemoreceptors in the carotid body detect CO2 and H+ changes. Statement (ii) is incorrect — the pneumotaxic centre reduces (not increases) the duration of inspiration. Statement (iv) is incorrect — the respiratory centre is in the medulla oblongata, not the cerebral cortex.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The pneumotaxic centre sends inhibitory signals to the inspiratory area, reducing inspiration duration. The respiratory centre is in the medulla oblongata.

questions.question_text:
Match the respiratory disorder with its characteristic feature:
(a) Asthma - (i) Damage to alveolar walls
(b) Emphysema - (ii) Fibrosis of upper lung due to exposure to silica dust
(c) Silicosis - (iii) Bronchospasm and airway inflammation
(d) Lung cancer - (iv) Uncontrolled proliferation of lung cells
Select the correct option:
questions.explanation_correct: Asthma involves bronchospasm and airway inflammation. Emphysema involves damage to alveolar walls. Silicosis is an occupational disease caused by chronic exposure to silica dust, leading to lung fibrosis. Lung cancer involves uncontrolled cell proliferation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Each respiratory disorder has distinct pathological features. The correct matching follows the standard NCERT descriptions.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an occupational respiratory disorder caused by long-term exposure to asbestos fibres?
questions.explanation_correct: Asbestosis is an occupational lung disease caused by chronic inhalation of asbestos fibres. It leads to pulmonary fibrosis (scarring of lung tissue), reducing lung compliance and gas exchange capacity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Silicosis is caused by silica dust. Emphysema is caused primarily by smoking. Bronchitis is inflammation of the bronchi, usually caused by infection or smoking.

questions.question_text: A person who is a chronic smoker is most likely to develop:
questions.explanation_correct: Chronic smoking is the major risk factor for both emphysema (destruction of alveolar walls) and lung cancer (uncontrolled proliferation of cells in the respiratory tract). Cigarette smoke contains carcinogens and irritants that damage lung tissue over time.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Silicosis is caused by silica dust exposure. Asbestosis is caused by asbestos exposure. Allergic rhinitis is caused by allergens. These are not primarily associated with smoking.

questions.question_text:
Assertion (A): The pneumotaxic centre can alter the respiratory rate.
Reason (R): Signals from the pneumotaxic centre can reduce the duration of inspiration and thereby alter the respiratory rate.
Select the correct option:

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true but R is false.
A is false but R is true.

questions.explanation_correct: Both are true and the reason correctly explains the assertion. The pneumotaxic centre (in the pons) sends signals to the inspiratory area in the medulla to limit the duration of inspiration. By reducing inspiration time, the respiratory rate increases, and vice versa.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The reason accurately explains the mechanism by which the pneumotaxic centre alters respiratory rate.

questions.question_text: The total lung capacity (TLC) of a person is 6000 mL and the vital capacity (VC) is 4800 mL. The residual volume (RV) is:
questions.explanation_correct: Total Lung Capacity (TLC) = Vital Capacity (VC) + Residual Volume (RV). Therefore, RV = TLC - VC = 6000 - 4800 = 1200 mL.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The calculation is straightforward: RV = TLC - VC = 6000 - 4800 = 1200 mL. Other values would result from incorrect calculations.

questions.question_text:
The diffusion membrane at the alveolar-capillary interface is made up of:
(i) Thin squamous epithelium of alveoli
(ii) Endothelium of blood capillaries
(iii) Basement membranes of both layers
Which of the above form the respiratory membrane?
questions.explanation_correct: The diffusion membrane (respiratory membrane) consists of three layers: (i) thin squamous epithelium of the alveolar wall, (ii) endothelium of the pulmonary blood capillary, and (iii) the basement membranes of both these layers (which may be fused). This membrane is extremely thin (~0.2 mm) to facilitate rapid gas exchange.
questions.explanation_incorrect: All three components form the complete diffusion membrane. Missing any one would give an incomplete description.

questions.question_text: Surfactant is secreted by which cells in the alveoli?

options.text: Type II alveolar cells (great alveolar cells)

questions.explanation_correct: Surfactant is a phospholipid-rich substance secreted by Type II alveolar cells (also called great alveolar cells or septal cells). Surfactant reduces the surface tension of the alveolar fluid, preventing the alveoli from collapsing during expiration.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Type I cells are thin squamous cells forming the gas exchange surface. Alveolar macrophages engulf foreign particles. Goblet cells secrete mucus in the airways, not surfactant.

questions.question_text: Carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning is dangerous because CO:

options.text: binds to haemoglobin with about 200 times greater affinity than O2, forming stable carboxyhaemoglobin.
increases the production of CO2 in tissues.

questions.explanation_correct: Carbon monoxide (CO) is extremely dangerous because it binds to the iron atom of haemoglobin with about 200 times greater affinity than oxygen, forming a very stable compound called carboxyhaemoglobin (HbCO). This prevents haemoglobin from carrying oxygen, leading to tissue hypoxia and potentially death.
questions.explanation_incorrect: CO does not destroy RBCs, increase CO2 production or damage alveolar walls. Its danger lies in its high affinity binding to haemoglobin, blocking O2 transport.

questions.question_text: During vigorous exercise, which of the following changes occur?

options.text: Breathing rate decreases and tidal volume decreases.
Breathing rate increases and tidal volume increases.
Breathing rate increases but tidal volume remains unchanged.
Breathing rate remains unchanged but tidal volume increases.

questions.explanation_correct: During vigorous exercise, the body's demand for O2 increases and more CO2 is produced. The respiratory centre responds by increasing both the breathing rate and the tidal volume (depth of breathing), thereby increasing pulmonary ventilation to meet the increased demand.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both rate and depth of breathing increase during exercise. Neither remains unchanged nor decreases during vigorous physical activity.

questions.question_text: The role of the pneumotaxic centre is to:

options.text: stimulate the inspiratory centre to increase the duration of inspiration.
moderate the functions of the respiratory centre and limit inspiration duration.
detect changes in blood CO2 levels.
control the contraction of the diaphragm directly.

questions.explanation_correct: The pneumotaxic centre (in the pons) moderates the activity of the respiratory centre in the medulla. It sends inhibitory signals to limit the duration of inspiration. This helps in fine-tuning the respiratory rate and ensuring smooth, rhythmic breathing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The pneumotaxic centre inhibits (not stimulates) the inspiratory centre. CO2 detection is done by chemoreceptors. Direct diaphragm control is through the phrenic nerve from the spinal cord.

questions.question_text: A patient with emphysema would show which of the following changes in pulmonary function?

options.text: Increased vital capacity and decreased residual volume
Decreased vital capacity and increased residual volume
Normal vital capacity and residual volume
Increased tidal volume and decreased total lung capacity

questions.explanation_correct: In emphysema, alveolar walls are destroyed and the lungs lose their elastic recoil. This leads to air trapping, increasing the residual volume. The destruction of alveoli reduces the effective gas exchange area and decreases vital capacity. Patients have difficulty expelling air, leading to barrel-shaped chest.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Emphysema does not increase vital capacity or maintain normal values. The loss of elastic recoil and air trapping increase RV while decreasing VC.
